questions.questionText: A person buys a chair for Rs. 600 and sells it for Rs. 750. What is the profit percentage?
If an article is sold for Rs. 240 at a loss of 20%, what was its cost price?
A shopkeeper marks an article 40% above the cost price and gives a discount of 20%. What is his profit percentage?
questions.explanation: Let CP = 100. MP = 140 (40% above CP). After 20% discount: SP = 140 × 80 ÷ 100 = 112. Profit = 112 - 100 = 12. Profit % = 12%.

questions.questionText: An article marked at Rs. 1200 is sold at a discount of 25%. What is the selling price?
A trader buys goods worth Rs. 5000 and sells them at a loss of 15%. What is the selling price?
What is the single equivalent discount for two successive discounts of 20% and 30%?
A shopkeeper buys an article for Rs. 800 and wants to make a profit of 25%. What should be the selling price?
A person sells two articles for Rs. 990 each. On one he gains 10% and on the other he loses 10%. What is his overall gain or loss percentage?
questions.explanation: When SP is same for both articles with equal profit% and loss%, there is always a loss. Loss % = (Common profit or loss %)² ÷ 100 = 10² ÷ 100 = 100 ÷ 100 = 1% loss.

questions.questionText: A shopkeeper uses 900 gm weight instead of 1 kg and claims to sell at cost price. What is his actual profit percentage?
questions.explanation: Error = 1000 - 900 = 100 gm. Profit % = (Error ÷ True weight given) × 100 = (100 ÷ 900) × 100 = 11.11%.

questions.questionText: A shopkeeper marks his goods 50% above the cost price. What discount percentage should he give to make 20% profit?
questions.explanation: Let CP = 100. MP = 150 (50% above). For 20% profit, SP = 120. Discount = 150 - 120 = 30. Discount % = (30 ÷ 150) × 100 = 20%.

questions.questionText: A and B start a business with investments of Rs. 8000 and Rs. 12000 respectively. If the profit at the end of the year is Rs. 5000, what is B's share?
questions.explanation: Ratio of investments = 8000:12000 = 2:3. Total parts = 5. B's share = (3 ÷ 5) × 5000 = Rs. 3000.

questions.questionText: By selling an article for Rs. 432, a person loses 10%. At what price should he sell it to gain 10%?
A trader marks his goods 30% above cost price and allows a discount of 15%. What is his profit percentage?

questions.questionText: A fruit seller buys oranges at Rs. 10 per dozen and sells them at Rs. 12 per 10 oranges. What is his profit or loss percentage?
A trader allows a trade discount of 10% and a cash discount of 5% on the marked price. What is the net selling price of an article marked at Rs. 2000?
questions.explanation: After 10% discount: Price = 2000 × 90 ÷ 100 = Rs. 1800. After 5% discount on 1800: Price = 1800 × 95 ÷ 100 = Rs. 1710. Or use successive discount formula: Single discount = [10 + 5 - (10 × 5 ÷ 100)] = 14.5%. SP = 2000 × 85.5 ÷ 100 = Rs. 1710.

questions.questionText: If the cost price of 12 pens is equal to the selling price of 10 pens, what is the profit percentage?
questions.explanation: CP of 12 pens = SP of 10 pens. Let CP of 1 pen = x. So, 12x = SP of 10 pens. SP of 1 pen = 12x/10 = 1.2x. Profit per pen = 1.2x - x = 0.2x. Profit % = (0.2x ÷ x) × 100 = 20%.

questions.questionText: A, B, and C start a business with investments of Rs. 5000, Rs. 6000, and Rs. 9000 respectively. If the profit at the end of the year is Rs. 8000, what is the share of A?
questions.explanation: Ratio of investments = 5000:6000:9000 = 5:6:9. Total parts = 5 + 6 + 9 = 20. A's share = (5 ÷ 20) × 8000 = Rs. 2000.
